Hymn - Vedaveda or Vedaveda of praise , the R2igfg-vedaveda, or most ancient sacred book of the Hindu1sHindus (that is, the collective body of sacred verses called R2icasfcas [see below], consisting of 1017 hymns [or with the Va1lakhilyasvAlaKilyas 1028] arranged in eight Asht2akasazwakas or in ten Man2d2alasmaRqalas ; Man2d2alasmaRqalas 2-8 contain groups of hymns, each group ascribed to one author or to the members of one family ; the ninth book contains the hymns sung at the Somasoma ceremonies ; the first and tenth contain hymns of a different character, some comparatively modern, composed by a greater variety of individual authors ; in its wider sense the term R2igfg-vedaveda comprehends the Bra1hman2asbrAhmaRas and the Su1trasUtra works on the ritual connected with the hymns) AitBr.; S3Br.; Mn. &c225,1 38737

m. an artist, one who works in iron, a smith, builder (of carriages &c), N. of three semi-divine beings (R2ibhufBu, Va1javAja, and VibhvanviBvan, the name of the first being applied to all of them ; thought by some to represent the three seasons of the year [Ludwig RV. vol.iii, p.187], and celebrated for their skill as artists ; they are supposed to dwell in the solar sphere, and are the artists who formed the horses of Indraindra, the carriage of the As3vinsaSvins, and the miraculous cow of Br2ihaspatibfhaspati ; they made their parents young, and performed other wonderful works [Sv-apas] ; they are supposed to take their ease and remain idle for twelve days [the twelve intercalary days of the winter solstice] every year in the house of the Sun [Agohya] ; after which they recommence working ; when the gods heard of their skill, they sent Agniagni to them with the one cup of their rival Tvasht2r2itvazwf, the artificer of the gods, bidding the R2ibhusfBus construct four cups from it ; when they had successfully executed this task, the gods received the R2ibhusfBus amongst themselves and allowed them to partake of their sacrifices &c ; cf. Kaegi RV. p.53 f.;) RV.; AV. &c226,2 38960

(2. fz Comm. on Un2. iv, 119 ; fzati jYAnena saMsAra-pAram T. ; perhaps fr. an obsolete fz for dfS, to , see ? cf. fzi-kft), a singer of sacred hymns, an inspired poet or sage, any person who alone or with others invokes the deities in rhythmical speech or song of a sacred character (e.g. the ancient hymn-singers Kutsakutsa, Atriatri, RebhareBa, Agastyaagastya, Kus3ikakuSika, Vasisht2havasizWa, Vy-as3vavy-aSva) RV.; AV.; VS. &c226,3 39047

m. the R2ishisfzis were regarded by later generations as patriarchal sages or saints, occupying the same position in India history as the heroes and patriarchs of other countries, and constitute a peculiar class of beings in the early mythical system, as distinct from gods, men, Asurasasuras, &c AV. x, 10, 26; S3Br.; AitBr.; Ka1tyS3r.; Mn. &c226,3 39048

m. they are the authors or rather seers of the Vedic hymns i.e. according to orthodox Hindu1Hindu ideas they are the inspired personages to whom these hymns were revealed, and such an expression as the R2ishifzi says is equivalent to so it stands in the sacred text Page227,1 39049

m. seven R2ishisfzis, sapta fzayaH, or saptafzayaH or saptarzayaH, are often mentioned in the Bra1hman2asbrAhmaRas and later works as typical representatives of the character and spirit of the pre-historic or mythical period227,1 39050

m. in S3Br. xiv, 5, 2, 6 their names are given as follows, Gotamagotama, Bharadva1jaBaradvAja, Vis3va1-mitraviSvA-mitra, Jamadagnijamadagni, Vasisht2havasizWa, Kas3yapakaSyapa, and Atriatri227,1 39051

m. in MBh. xii, Mari1cimarIci, Atriatri, An3girasaNgiras, Pulahapulaha, Kratukratu, Pulastyapulastya, Vasisht2havasizWa are given as the names of the R2ishisfzis of the first Manvantaramanvantara, and they are also called Praja1patisprajApatis or patriarchs 227,1 39052
m. the names of the R2ishisfzis of the subsequent Manv-antarasmanv-antaras are enumerated in Hariv. 417 ff.227,1 39053

m. afterwards three other names are added, viz. Pracetaspracetas or Dakshadakza, Bhr2iguBfgu, and Na1radanArada, these ten being created by Manumanu Sva1yambhuvasvAyamBuva for the production of all other beings including gods and men A1s3vS3r.; MBh.; VP. &c227,1 39054
m. in astron. the seven R2ishisfzis form the constellation of the Great Bear RV. x, 82, 2; AV. vi, 40, 1; S3Br.; A1s3vGr2.; MBh. &c227,1 39055
m. (metaphorically the seven R2ishisfzis may stand for the seven senses or the seven vital airs of the body VS. xxxiv S3Br. xiv Ka1tyS3r.)227,1 39056

entry.sense: mfn. (Gr. 223 ; g. sarvAdi Pa1n2. 1-1, 27) this, this here, here (especially as pointing to what is nearest to the speaker e.g. eza bARaH, this arrow here in my hand ; eza yAti panTAH, here passes the way ; eza kAlaH, here i.e. now, is the time ; etad, this here i.e. this world here below)231,2 40041

mfn. sometimes used to give emphasis to the personal pronouns (e.g. ezo'ham, I, this very person here) or with omission of those pronouns (e.g. eza tvAM svargaM nayAmi, I standing here will convey thee to heaven ; etO pravizwO svaH, we two here have entered)231,2 40042

mfn. as the subject of a sentence it agrees in gender and number with the predicate without reference to the noun to be supplied (e.g. etad eva hi me Danam, for this [scil. cow] is my only wealth MBh.)231,2 40043
mfn. but sometimes the neuter sing. remains (e.g. etad guruzu vfttiH, this is the custom among Gurusgurus Mn. ii, 206)231,2 40044

mfn. etad generally refers to what precedes, esp. when connected with idam, the latter then referring to what follows (e.g. eza vE praTamaH kalpaH anukalpas tv ayaM jYeyaH, this before-mentioned is the principal rule, but this following may be considered a secondary rule Mn. iii, 147)231,2 40045

mfn. it refers also to that which follows, esp. when connected with a relative clause (e.g. eza cEva gurur Darmo yam pravakzyAmy ahaM tava, this is the important law, which I will proclaim to you MBh.;) RV. &c231,2 40046

ind. (in the Sam2hita1saMhitA also ev/A) (i Un2. i, 152 ; fr. pronom. base e BRD., probably connected with 2. /eva), so, just so, exactly so (in the sense of the later evam) RV.; AV. 232,2 40181
ind. indeed, truly, really (often at the beginning of a verse in conjunction with other particles, as id, hi) RV. 232,2 40181.1

ind. (in its most frequent use of strengthening the idea expressed by any word, eva must be variously rendered by such adverbs as) just, exactly, very, same, only, even, alone, merely, immediately on, still, already, &c (e.g. tvam eva yantA nAnyo 'sti pfTivyAm, thou alone art a charioteer, no other is on earth, i.e. thou art the best charioteer MBh. iii, 2825 ; tAvatIm eva rAtrim, just so long as a night ; evam eva or taTEva, exactly so, in this manner only ; in the same manner as above ; tenEva mantreRa, with the same Mantramantra as above ; apaH spfzwvEva, by merely touching water ; tAn eva, these very persons ; na cirAd eva, in no long time at all ; japyenEva, by sole repetition ; aBuktvEva, even without having eaten ; iti vadann eva, at the very moment of saying so ; sa jIvann eva, he while still living, &c) RV. &c MBh. &c 232,2 40181.2

ind. (sometimes, esp. in connection with other adverbs, eva is a mere expletive without any exact meaning and not translatable e.g. tv eva, cEva, eva ca, &c ; according to native authorities eva implies emphasis, affirmation, detraction, diminution, command, restrainment) ; ([cf. Zd. aeva ; Goth. aiv ; Old Germ. eo, io ; Mod. Germ. je.]) 027577 232,2 40181.3

entry.sense: ind. (fr. pronom. base e BRD. ; probably connected with 1. ev/a), thus, in this way, in such a manner, such, (it is not found in the oldest hymns of the Vedaveda, where its place is taken by 1. ev/a, but occurs in later hymns ind. in the Bra1hman2asbrAhmaRas, especially in connection with vid, to know , and its derivatives [e.g. ya evaM veda, he who knows so ; cf. evaM-v/id, col.3] ; in classical Sanskr2itSanskrit evam occurs very frequently, especially in connection with the roots vac, to speak , and Sru, to hear , and refers to what precedes as well as to what follows [e.g. evam uktvA, having so said Page232,3 ; evam evEtat, this is so ; evam astuorevam Bavatu, be it so, I assent ; asty evam, it is so ; yady evam, if this be so ; kim evam, how so? what is the meaning of it? what does this refer to? mEvam, not so! evam - yaTA or yaTA - evam, so - as]) Mn.; S3ak. &c 232,2 40194

ind. (av Un2. i, 141 ; originally oM = AM, which may be derived from A BRD.), a word of solemn affirmation and respectful assent, sometimes translated by yes, verily, so be it (and in this sense compared with Amen ; it is placed at the commencement of most Hindu1Hindu works, and as a sacred exclamation may be uttered [but not so as to be heard by ears profane] at the beginning and end of a reading of the Vedasvedas or previously to any prayer ; it is also regarded as a particle of auspicious salutation [Hail!] ; om appears first in the Upanishadsupanizads as a mystic monosyllable, and is there set forth as the object of profound religious meditation, the highest spiritual efficacy being attributed not only to the whole word but also to the three sounds a, u, m, of which it consists ; in later times om is the mystic name for the Hindu1Hindu triad, and represents the union of the three gods, viz. a (Vishn2uvizRu), u (S3ivaSiva), m (Brahma1brahmA) ; it may also be typical of the three Vedasvedas ; om is usually called praRava, more rarely akzara, or ekAkzara, and only in later times oMkAra) VS.; S3Br.; ChUp. &c 235,3 40704

ind. (Buddhists place om at the beginning of their vidyA zaqakzarI or mystical formulary in six syllables [viz. om maRi padme hUM] ; according to T. om may be used in the following senses: praRave, AramBe, svIkAre, anumatO, apAkftO, asvIkAre, maNgale, SuBe, jYeye, brahmaRi ; with preceding a or A, the o of om does not form Vr2iddhivfdDi (O), but Gun2aguRa (o) Pa1n2. 6-1, 95.) 027941 235,3 40704.1
